settings.text: We are committed to making a meaningful difference in the lives of families with medically fragile children. Our journey began with a passion for healthcare and a desire to create a better, more supportive environment for those in need.

With years of experience as a registered nurse (BSN, RN) and specialized certifications in advanced life support (ALS), pediatric care (PALS), and more, our founder combines clinical expertise with compassionate care. This unique blend ensures that every policy and procedure we provide is crafted with both professional precision and heartfelt understanding.

Inspired by firsthand experiences in healthcare, we recognized the immense value of in-home care for children and the transformative impact it has on families. Today, we use that knowledge and passion to guide others in building successful in-home healthcare agencies. By offering comprehensive policies, procedures, and expert support, we help entrepreneurs bring joy and support to families while creating a lasting legacy of impact and income.

We’ve had the pleasure of attending festivals and events, bringing our homemade, nutrient-packed juices to help patrons refresh and detoxify.

Starting an in-home healthcare agency can feel like a huge leap—but it doesn’t have to be complicated. At Home Care Helpers, we’re here to make it simple and achievable with our customized policies and procedures designed to meet all state and federal requirements. Whether you’re focusing on skilled care, unskilled care, or specializing in services for medically fragile children, we’ve got everything you need to build a thriving business.

Will Our Policies and Procedures Work for You? Absolutely.

Let’s get straight to it: our policies and procedures are not just templates. They’re state-specific, fully customized, and proven to work. We’ve helped countless entrepreneurs, just like you, get approved for their Medicaid provider licenses and start delivering exceptional care.

Key Stats to Know:

  • 95% of our clients get approved within 6 months.
  • Some achieve approval in as little as 60 days (with the right preparation).
  • The typical approval timeline for most agencies without expert guidance is 8 months or longer.

When you choose our policies and procedures, you’re getting more than just a document—you’re getting a complete roadmap to start your agency without the stress.

How Do You Make Money in In-Home Healthcare?

This is one of the top questions we hear, and here’s the answer: the in-home healthcare industry is backed by Medicaid funding, meaning there’s a steady demand for quality providers. By offering skilled care (like nursing and therapy) or unskilled care (like personal assistance and daily living support), you can build a sustainable, profitable business while making a real impact on families in your community.

Do You Need Additional Consulting or Services?

Nope! When you work with Home Care Helpers, we provide everything you need to get started.

  • Policies and Procedures: Fully compliant and tailored to your state.
  • Business Plan: Designed to help you secure Medicaid approval and attract clients.
  • Checklist: Ensures you don’t miss a single step during the setup process.

We take the guesswork out of starting your agency so you can focus on what matters most—helping families and building your future.

What Sacrifices Will You Need to Make?

Starting an in-home healthcare agency takes work. You’ll need to invest time in understanding the licensing process, training staff, and building a network. But the good news is, with our guidance and resources, you can fast-track the process and avoid unnecessary headaches.

What You’ll Need:

  • Commitment: It takes focus and persistence to succeed, especially in the first year.
  • Financial Investment: Expect startup costs to range from $50,000 to $100,000, depending on your services.
  • Flexibility: Be ready to adjust as you grow and learn the business.

What You’ll Gain:

  • The freedom to run your own business.
  • The opportunity to help families with medically fragile children and other vulnerable populations.
  • A lucrative, stable career path supported by government funding.
